In the case of a sitting president, I agree that he cannot be indicted in office. A special counsel in such a case should present the facts for Congress and the American people, and he should simply and clearly provide his opinion on whether it otherwise would be prosecutable.

Whether it relates to Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, or Jussie Smollett, it’s inappropriate for a prosecutor to declare someone not exonerated. Either prosecute or don’t, but the burden of proof is on the government. We don’t say someone is “not exonerated” until proven guilty.

“The counsel of Gandalf was not founded on foreknowledge of safety, for himself or for others,” said Aragorn. “There are some things that it is better to begin than to refuse, even though the end may be dark.”

The rules were designed to facilitate public disclosure without threatening privacy or undermining a special counsel by requiring him to produce a public report. If that process fails, and the AG doesn’t provide appropriate transparency, Congress can *then* address it.

Mueller then has to write his report for a public audience, while knowing the public will hold him responsible for any fallout from the release. This could limit his ability to provide the AG all the appropriate information.
But if Congress insists now, before the report has been written, that the entire report be released, we effectively shift to Mueller the decisions about what to release publicly.

Mueller is required to write a report for the AG, who is then responsible for decisions about releasing information to the public. This is a valuable dynamic—it allows Mueller to put into his report exactly the information he thinks the AG should have.

#HConRes24 demands the public release of Mueller’s report to the AG without ensuring adequate privacy for legally innocent people mentioned in the report (which raises due process concerns), and the resolution also may undermine Mueller’s ability to give info to the AG. Thread:
